content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" is cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes key actions such as the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in February, the Budget Committees reporting on the budget by April 1, and Congress completing action on the budget by April 15. Additionally, biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill may be considered in the House by May 15, with the House Appropriations Committee reporting the last appropriation bill by June 10. Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by June 15, and the House completes action on biennial appropriation bills by June 30. The congressional budget process includes key actions like the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in February, Budget Committees reporting by April 1, and Congress completing action by April 15. Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by June 15, and on biennial appropriation bills by June 30. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will override the usual budget process timeline. The budget process timeline includes key actions to be completed by specific dates, such as the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in April, Congressional Budget Office submitting a report by April 15, and Budget Committees reporting a concurrent resolution on the budget by May 15. Congress must complete action on the budget resolution by June 1, with further deadlines for appropriation bills in July and August. The House completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by July 20, while Congress completes action on reconciliation legislation by August 1. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science. The text chunk states that Congress shall consider and enact annual defense appropriation bills and biennial appropriation bills for various departments and agencies. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The term 'biennium' is defined as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Amendments are made to committee allocations in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and defense. Amendments are made to committee allocations in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding appropriations for defense and each fiscal year in the biennium. Amendments are made to committee allocations in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding appropriations for defense and each fiscal year in the biennium. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to define "biennium" and adjust budget contents and submission to Congress for each fiscal year in the biennium and the following four fiscal years. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 redefine "biennium" and modify budget submission requirements for each fiscal year in the biennium and the subsequent four fiscal years. Amendments to title 31, United States Code, redefine budget submission requirements for each fiscal year in the biennium and the subsequent years. Amendments to title 31, United States Code redefine budget submission requirements for each fiscal year in the biennium and subsequent years, including changes to prior year outlays and receipts. Amendments to title 31, United States Code redefine budget submission requirements for each fiscal year in the biennium and subsequent years, including changes to prior year outlays and receipts. Changes include adjustments to estimated expenditures of the Legislative and Judicial Branches, recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies, and capital investment analysis. SEC. 5. TWO-YEAR APPROPRIATIONS; TITLE AND STYLE OF APPROPRIATIONS ACTS. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will follow a specific format for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will have a different format. All Acts making regular appropriations must detail the amounts provided for each fiscal year. The Government's support specifies appropriations for each fiscal year. Definitions for terms like 'biennium' are provided. A technical amendment is made to the table of sections in the United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the program will require no further appropriations. Exceptions include defense, privileged measures, Executive Session matters, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the program will require no further appropriations. Exceptions include defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings by relevant committees on agency activities not funded under certain conditions. The hearings review agency mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD is also mandated. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must assess the feasibility of transitioning to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process within 180 days of the Act's enactment. A report on the findings will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting in fiscal year 2017.
